data.label: Agent
data.name: seqAgent
data.description: Agent that can execute tools

inputParams.label: System Prompt
inputParams.name: systemMessagePrompt
inputParams.default: You are a research assistant who can search for up-to-date info using search engine.

inputParams.label: Prepend Messages History
inputParams.name: messageHistory
inputParams.description: Prepend a list of messages between System Prompt and Human Prompt. This is useful when you want to provide few shot examples

inputParams.label: Conversation History
inputParams.name: conversationHistorySelection

options.label: User Question
options.name: user_question
options.description: Use the user question from the historical conversation messages as input.

options.label: Last Conversation Message
options.name: last_message
options.description: Use the last conversation message from the historical conversation messages as input.

options.label: All Conversation Messages
options.name: all_messages
options.description: Use all conversation messages from the historical conversation messages as input.

options.label: Empty
options.name: empty
options.description: Do not use any messages from the conversation history. Ensure to use either System Prompt, Human Prompt, or Messages History.

inputParams.description: Select which messages from the conversation history to include in the prompt. The selected messages will be inserted between the System Prompt (if defined) and [Messages History, Human Prompt].

inputParams.label: Human Prompt
inputParams.name: humanMessagePrompt
inputParams.description: This prompt will be added at the end of the messages as human message

inputParams.label: Require Approval
inputParams.name: interrupt
inputParams.description:
Pause execution and request user approval before running tools.
If enabled, the agent will prompt the user with customizable approve/reject options
and will proceed only after approval. This requires a configured agent memory to manage
the state and handle approval requests.
If no tools are invoked, the agent proceeds without interruption.

inputParams.label: Format Prompt Values
inputParams.name: promptValues
inputParams.description: Assign values to the prompt variables. You can also use $flow.state.<variable-name> to get the state value

inputParams.label: Approval Prompt
inputParams.name: approvalPrompt
inputParams.description: Prompt for approval. Only applicable if "Require Approval" is enabled
inputParams.default: You are about to execute tool: {tools}. Ask if user want to proceed

inputParams.label: Approve Button Text
inputParams.name: approveButtonText
inputParams.description: Text for approve button. Only applicable if "Require Approval" is enabled

inputParams.label: Reject Button Text
inputParams.name: rejectButtonText
inputParams.description: Text for reject button. Only applicable if "Require Approval" is enabled

tabs.label: Update State (Table)
tabs.name: updateStateMemoryUI

hint.label: How to use
hint.value:
1. Key and value pair to be updated. For example: if you have the following State:
    | Key       | Operation     | Default Value     |
    |-----------|---------------|-------------------|
    | user      | Replace       |                   |

    You can update the "user" value with the following:
    | Key       | Value     |
    |-----------|-----------|
    | user      | john doe  |

2. If you want to use the Agent's output as the value to update state, it is available as available as `$flow.output` with the following structure:
    ```json
    {
        "content": "Hello! How can I assist you today?",
        "usedTools": [
            {
                "tool": "tool-name",
                "toolInput": "{foo: var}",
                "toolOutput": "This is the tool's output"
            }
        ],
        "sourceDocuments": [
            {
                "pageContent": "This is the page content",
                "metadata": "{foo: var}"
            }
        ]
    }
    ```

    For example, if the `toolOutput` is the value you want to update the state with, you can do the following:
    | Key       | Value                                     |
    |-----------|-------------------------------------------|
    | user      | `$flow.output.usedTools[0].toolOutput`  |

3. You can get default flow config, including the current "state":
    - `$flow.sessionId`
    - `$flow.chatId`
    - `$flow.chatflowId`
    - `$flow.input`
    - `$flow.state`

4. You can get custom variables: `$vars.<variable-name>`

tabs.description: This is only applicable when you have a custom State at the START node. After agent execution, you might want to update the State values

tabs.name: updateStateMemoryCode

data.label: State
data.name: seqState
data.description: A centralized state object, updated by nodes in the graph, passing from one node to another

tabs.label: Custom State (Table)
tabs.name: stateMemoryUI
tabs.description: Structure for state. By default, state contains "messages" that got updated with each message sent and received.

hint.label: How to use
hint.value:
Specify the Key, Operation Type, and Default Value for the state object. The Operation Type can be either "Replace" or "Append".

**Replace**
- Replace the existing value with the new value.
- If the new value is null, the existing value will be retained.

**Append**
- Append the new value to the existing value.
- Default value can be empty or an array. Ex: ["a", "b"]
- Final value is an array.

tabs.label: Custom State (Code)
tabs.name: stateMemoryCode
tabs.description: JSON object representing the state

outputAnchors.name: seqState
outputAnchors.label: State
outputAnchors.description: A centralized state object, updated by nodes in the graph, passing from one node to another

tabs.label: Update State (Table)
tabs.name: updateStateMemoryUI

hint.label: How to use
hint.value:
1. Key and value pair to be updated. For example: if you have the following State:
    | Key       | Operation     | Default Value     |
    |-----------|---------------|-------------------|
    | user      | Replace       |                   |

    You can update the "user" value with the following:
    | Key       | Value     |
    |-----------|-----------|
    | user      | john doe  |

2. If you want to use the LLM Node's output as the value to update state, it is available as available as `$flow.output` with the following structure:
    ```json
    {
        "content": 'Hello! How can I assist you today?',
        "name": "",
        "additional_kwargs": {},
        "response_metadata": {},
        "tool_calls": [],
        "invalid_tool_calls": [],
        "usage_metadata": {}
    }
    ```

    For example, if the output `content` is the value you want to update the state with, you can do the following:
    | Key       | Value                     |
    |-----------|---------------------------|
    | user      | `$flow.output.content`  |

3. You can get default flow config, including the current "state":
    - `$flow.sessionId`
    - `$flow.chatId`
    - `$flow.chatflowId`
    - `$flow.input`
    - `$flow.state`

4. You can get custom variables: `$vars.<variable-name>`

tabs.description: This is only applicable when you have a custom State at the START node. After agent execution, you might want to update the State values

tabs.label: Update State (Code)
tabs.name: updateStateMemoryCode

hint.label: How to use
hint.value:
1. Return the key value JSON object. For example: if you have the following State:
    ```json
    {
        "user": null
    }
    ```

    You can update the "user" value by returning the following:
    ```js
    return {
        "user": "john doe"
    }
    ```

2. If you want to use the LLM Node's output as the value to update state, it is available as `$flow.output` with the following structure:
    ```json
    {
        "content": 'Hello! How can I assist you today?',
        "name": "",
        "additional_kwargs": {},
        "response_metadata": {},
        "tool_calls": [],
        "invalid_tool_calls": [],
        "usage_metadata": {}
    }
    ```

    For example, if the output `content` is the value you want to update the state with, you can return the following:
    ```js
    return {
        "user": $flow.output.content
    }
    ```

3. You can also get default flow config, including the current "state":
    - `$flow.sessionId`
    - `$flow.chatId`
    - `$flow.chatflowId`
    - `$flow.input`
    - `$flow.state`

4. You can get custom variables: `$vars.<variable-name>`

tabs.description: This is only applicable when you have a custom State at the START node. After agent execution, you might want to update the State values. Must return an object representing the state

inputs.systemMessagePrompt:
You are Supervisor, an AI agent created by BarrelOfLube and inspired from Manus.

You excel at the following tasks:
1. Information gathering, fact-checking, and documentation
2. Data processing, analysis, and visualization
3. Writing multi-chapter articles and in-depth research reports
4. Creating websites, applications, and tools
5. Using programming to solve various problems beyond development
6. Various tasks that can be accomplished using computers and the internet

Default working language: English
Use the language specified by user in messages as the working language when explicitly provided
All thinking and responses must be in the working language
Natural language arguments in tool calls must be in the working language
Avoid using pure lists and bullet points format in any language

System capabilities:
- Access a Linux sandbox environment with internet connection
- Use shell, text editor, browser, and other software
- Write and run code in Python and various programming languages
- Independently install required software packages and dependencies via shell
- Access and browse the web
- Utilize various tools to complete user-assigned tasks step by step

Current Plan:
{plan}

You operate in an agent loop, iteratively completing tasks through these steps:
1. Analyze Events: Understand user needs and current state through event stream, focusing on latest user messages and execution results
2. Select Tools: Choose next tool call based on current state, task planning, relevant knowledge and available data APIs
3. Wait for Execution: Selected tool action will be executed by sandbox environment with new observations added to event stream
4. Iterate: Choose only one tool call per iteration, patiently repeat above steps until task completion
5. Submit Results: Send results to user via message tools, providing deliverables and related files as message attachments
6. Finally: Enter FINISH state when all tasks are completed.
inputs.llmStructuredOutput: [{"key":"next","type":"Enum","enumValues":"FINISH, FileWizard, CommandRunner, WebNavigator, PlanManager, Knowledgebase","description":"","actions":"","id":0},{"key":"instruction","type":"String","enumValues":"","description":"The specific instructions of the sub-task the next role should accomplish.","actions":"","id":1}]

options.description: Use all conversation messages from the historical conversation messages as input.

options.description: Do not use any messages from the conversation history. Ensure to use either System Prompt, Human Prompt, or Messages History.

tabs.label: Update State (Table)
tabs.name: updateStateMemoryUI

hint.label: How to use
hint.value:
1. Key and value pair to be updated. For example: if you have the following State:
    | Key       | Operation     | Default Value     |
    |-----------|---------------|-------------------|
    | user      | Replace       |                   |

    You can update the "user" value with the following:
    | Key       | Value     |
    |-----------|-----------|
    | user      | john doe  |

2. If you want to use the LLM Node's output as the value to update state, it is available as available as `$flow.output` with the following structure:
    ```json
    {
        "content": 'Hello! How can I assist you today?',
        "name": "",
        "additional_kwargs": {},
        "response_metadata": {},
        "tool_calls": [],
        "invalid_tool_calls": [],
        "usage_metadata": {}
    }
    ```

    For example, if the output `content` is the value you want to update the state with, you can do the following:
    | Key       | Value                     |
    |-----------|---------------------------|
    | user      | `$flow.output.content`  |

3. You can get default flow config, including the current "state":
    - `$flow.sessionId`
    - `$flow.chatId`
    - `$flow.chatflowId`
    - `$flow.input`
    - `$flow.state`

4. You can get custom variables: `$vars.<variable-name>`

tabs.description: This is only applicable when you have a custom State at the START node. After agent execution, you might want to update the State values

tabs.label: Update State (Code)
tabs.name: updateStateMemoryCode

hint.label: How to use
hint.value:
1. Return the key value JSON object. For example: if you have the following State:
    ```json
    {
        "user": null
    }
    ```

    You can update the "user" value by returning the following:
    ```js
    return {
        "user": "john doe"
    }
    ```

2. If you want to use the LLM Node's output as the value to update state, it is available as `$flow.output` with the following structure:
    ```json
    {
        "content": 'Hello! How can I assist you today?',
        "name": "",
        "additional_kwargs": {},
        "response_metadata": {},
        "tool_calls": [],
        "invalid_tool_calls": [],
        "usage_metadata": {}
    }
    ```

    For example, if the output `content` is the value you want to update the state with, you can return the following:
    ```js
    return {
        "user": $flow.output.content
    }
    ```

3. You can also get default flow config, including the current "state":
    - `$flow.sessionId`
    - `$flow.chatId`
    - `$flow.chatflowId`
    - `$flow.input`
    - `$flow.state`

4. You can get custom variables: `$vars.<variable-name>`

tabs.description: This is only applicable when you have a custom State at the START node. After agent execution, you might want to update the State values. Must return an object representing the state

inputAnchors.label: Chat Model
inputAnchors.name: model
inputAnchors.description: Overwrite model to be used for this node

inputs.systemMessagePrompt:
You are a strategic planning and plan management expert who specializes in breaking complex tasks into manageable steps with clear dependencies and tracking progress. Your role is to:

1. Analyze user objectives thoroughly before planning

2. Design efficient execution paths with realistic timelines

3. Present plans using structured markdown with checkable tasks and subtasks

4. Track progress by updating task completion status

5. Adapt plans when circumstances change

You will create and maintain structured plans with:

- âœ… Completed tasks marked with checkboxes

- â¬œ Pending tasks clearly identified

- ðŸ“Š Clear task dependencies and relationships

- ðŸš§ Realtime Potential obstacles and mitigation strategies

- ðŸ“ Required resources for successful execution

When developing plans:

- Use hierarchical task breakdowns (main tasks â†’ subtasks â†’ action items)

- Include measurable milestones to track progress

- Provide multiple approaches when relevant, with pros/cons

- Balance thoroughness with efficiency

- Clarify ambiguous goals before detailed planning

- Regularly update and adapt the plan as progress occurs

You will automatically use markdown formatting for all plans, including:

- Task hierarchies with proper indentation

- Checkboxes for completion tracking

- Nested lists for subtasks

- Bold and italic text for emphasis

- Tables for comparing options when appropriate

- Headers for organizing different plan sections

As tasks are completed, you will update the plan by checking off completed items and adjusting remaining tasks as needed.

Current Plan:

{current_plan}

outputAnchors.name: seqLLMNode
outputAnchors.label: LLMNode
outputAnchors.description: Run Chat Model and return the output

data.label: Unstructured File Loader
data.name: unstructuredFileLoader
data.description: Use Unstructured.io to load data from a file path

inputParams.label: Files Upload
inputParams.name: fileObject
inputParams.description: Files to be processed. Multiple files can be uploaded.

inputParams.label: Unstructured API URL
inputParams.name: unstructuredAPIUrl
inputParams.description: Unstructured API URL. Read more on how to get started

inputParams.label: Strategy
inputParams.name: strategy
inputParams.description: The strategy to use for partitioning PDF/image. Options are fast, hi_res, auto. Default: auto.

inputParams.label: Encoding
inputParams.name: encoding
inputParams.description: The encoding method used to decode the text input. Default: utf-8.

inputParams.label: Skip Infer Table Types
inputParams.name: skipInferTableTypes
inputParams.description: The document types that you want to skip table extraction with. Default: pdf, jpg, png.

inputParams.label: Hi-Res Model Name
inputParams.name: hiResModelName
inputParams.description: The name of the inference model used when strategy is hi_res

options.label: chipper
options.name: chipper
options.description: Exlusive to Unstructured hosted API. The Chipper model is Unstructured in-house image-to-text model based on transformer-based Visual Document Understanding (VDU) models.

options.label: detectron2_onnx
options.name: detectron2_onnx
options.description: A Computer Vision model by Facebook AI that provides object detection and segmentation algorithms with ONNX Runtime. It is the fastest model with the hi_res strategy.

options.label: yolox
options.name: yolox
options.description: A single-stage real-time object detector that modifies YOLOv3 with a DarkNet53 backbone.

options.label: yolox_quantized
options.name: yolox_quantized
options.description: Runs faster than YoloX and its speed is closer to Detectron2.

inputParams.label: Chunking Strategy
inputParams.name: chunkingStrategy
inputParams.description: Use one of the supported strategies to chunk the returned elements. When omitted, no chunking is performed and any other chunking parameters provided are ignored. Default: by_title

inputParams.label: OCR Languages
inputParams.name: ocrLanguages
inputParams.description: The languages to use for OCR. Note: Being depricated as languages is the new type. Pending langchain update.

inputParams.label: Source ID Key
inputParams.name: sourceIdKey
inputParams.description: Key used to get the true source of document, to be compared against the record. Document metadata must contain the Source ID Key.

inputParams.label: Coordinates
inputParams.name: coordinates
inputParams.description: If true, return coordinates for each element. Default: false.

inputParams.label: XML Keep Tags
inputParams.name: xmlKeepTags
inputParams.description: If True, will retain the XML tags in the output. Otherwise it will simply extract the text from within the tags. Only applies to partition_xml.

inputParams.label: Include Page Breaks
inputParams.name: includePageBreaks
inputParams.description: When true, the output will include page break elements when the filetype supports it.

inputParams.label: XML Keep Tags
inputParams.name: xmlKeepTags
inputParams.description: Whether to keep XML tags in the output.

inputParams.label: Multi-Page Sections
inputParams.name: multiPageSections
inputParams.description: Whether to treat multi-page documents as separate sections.

inputParams.label: Combine Under N Chars
inputParams.name: combineUnderNChars
inputParams.description: If chunking strategy is set, combine elements until a section reaches a length of n chars. Default: value of max_characters. Can't exceed value of max_characters.

inputParams.label: New After N Chars
inputParams.name: newAfterNChars
inputParams.description: If chunking strategy is set, cut off new sections after reaching a length of n chars (soft max). value of max_characters. Can't exceed value of max_characters.

inputParams.label: Max Characters
inputParams.name: maxCharacters
inputParams.description: If chunking strategy is set, cut off new sections after reaching a length of n chars (hard max). Default: 500

inputParams.label: Additional Metadata
inputParams.name: metadata
inputParams.description: Additional metadata to be added to the extracted documents

inputParams.label: Omit Metadata Keys
inputParams.name: omitMetadataKeys
inputParams.description: Each document loader comes with a default set of metadata keys that are extracted from the document. You can use this field to omit some of the default metadata keys. The value should be a list of keys, seperated by comma. Use * to omit all metadata keys execept the ones you specify in the Additional Metadata field

outputAnchors.name: output
outputAnchors.label: Output
outputAnchors.description: Array of document objects containing metadata and pageContent

options.name: document
options.label: Document
options.description: Array of document objects containing metadata and pageContent

options.name: text
options.label: Text
options.description: Concatenated string from pageContent of documents

data.label: Set Variable
data.name: setVariable
data.description: Set variable which can be retrieved at a later stage. Variable is only available during runtime.

inputParams.label: Show Output
inputParams.name: showOutput
inputParams.description: Show the output result in the Prediction API response

data.label: Sticky Note
data.name: stickyNote
data.description: Add a sticky note

inputs.note:
Upload your files here

Run: 
```docker run -p 8000:8000 -d --rm --name unstructured-api downloads.unstructured.io/unstructured-io/unstructured-api:latest```

outputAnchors.name: stickyNote
outputAnchors.label: StickyNote
outputAnchors.description: Add a sticky note

inputParams.description: When should agent uses to retrieve documents
inputParams.placeholder: Searches and returns documents regarding the state-of-the-union.

inputParams.label: Additional Metadata Filter

inputParams.description: Add additional metadata filter on top of the existing filter from vector store

hint.label: What can you filter?

Add additional filters to vector store. You can also filter with flow config, including the current "state":
- `$flow.sessionId`
- `$flow.chatId`
- `$flow.chatflowId`
- `$flow.input`
- `$flow.state`

You are an expert customer support routing system.
Your job is to detect whether a customer support representative is routing a user to the technical support team, or just responding conversationally.

inputParams.description: Select which messages from the conversation history to include in the prompt. The selected messages will be inserted between the System Prompt (if defined) and Human Prompt.

inputParams.label: Human Prompt
inputParams.name: humanMessagePrompt
inputParams.description: This prompt will be added at the end of the messages as human message
inputParams.default:
The previous conversation is an interaction between a customer support representative and a user.
Extract whether the representative is routing the user to the technical support team, or just responding conversationally.

If representative want to route the user to the technical support team, respond only with the word "TECHNICAL".
Otherwise, respond only with the word "CONVERSATION".

Remember, only respond with one of the above words.

inputs.systemMessagePrompt:
You are a grader assessing relevance of a retrieved document to a user question.

Here is the retrieved document:
{context}

Here is the user question: {question}

If the document contains keyword(s) or semantic meaning related to the user question, grade it as relevant.

Give a binary score 'yes' or 'no' score to indicate whether the document is relevant to the question.

Remember, always use the extract tool to output only "yes" or "no"
inputs.humanMessagePrompt:
The previous conversation is an interaction between a bot and a user.
Extract whether the if the document contains keyword(s) or semantic meaning related to the user question, grade it as relevant.

Give a binary score 'yes' or 'no' score to indicate whether the document is relevant to the question.

If document is relavant to question, respond only with the word "yes".
Otherwise, respond only with the word "no".

Remember, always use the extract tool to output only "yes" or "no"

tabs.label: Update State (Table)
tabs.name: updateStateMemoryUI

hint.label: How to use
hint.value:
1. Key and value pair to be updated. For example: if you have the following State:
    | Key       | Operation     | Default Value     |
    |-----------|---------------|-------------------|
    | user      | Replace       |                   |

    You can update the "user" value with the following:
    | Key       | Value     |
    |-----------|-----------|
    | user      | john doe  |

2. If you want to use the LLM Node's output as the value to update state, it is available as available as `$flow.output` with the following structure:
    ```json
    {
        "content": 'Hello! How can I assist you today?',
        "name": "",
        "additional_kwargs": {},
        "response_metadata": {},
        "tool_calls": [],
        "invalid_tool_calls": [],
        "usage_metadata": {}
    }
    ```

    For example, if the output `content` is the value you want to update the state with, you can do the following:
    | Key       | Value                     |
    |-----------|---------------------------|
    | user      | `$flow.output.content`  |

3. You can get default flow config, including the current "state":
    - `$flow.sessionId`
    - `$flow.chatId`
    - `$flow.chatflowId`
    - `$flow.input`
    - `$flow.state`

4. You can get custom variables: `$vars.<variable-name>`

tabs.description: This is only applicable when you have a custom State at the START node. After agent execution, you might want to update the State values

tabs.label: Update State (Code)
tabs.name: updateStateMemoryCode

hint.label: How to use
hint.value:
1. Return the key value JSON object. For example: if you have the following State:
    ```json
    {
        "user": null
    }
    ```

    You can update the "user" value by returning the following:
    ```js
    return {
        "user": "john doe"
    }
    ```

2. If you want to use the LLM Node's output as the value to update state, it is available as `$flow.output` with the following structure:
    ```json
    {
        "content": 'Hello! How can I assist you today?',
        "name": "",
        "additional_kwargs": {},
        "response_metadata": {},
        "tool_calls": [],
        "invalid_tool_calls": [],
        "usage_metadata": {}
    }
    ```

    For example, if the output `content` is the value you want to update the state with, you can return the following:
    ```js
    return {
        "user": $flow.output.content
    }
    ```

3. You can also get default flow config, including the current "state":
    - `$flow.sessionId`
    - `$flow.chatId`
    - `$flow.chatflowId`
    - `$flow.input`
    - `$flow.state`

4. You can get custom variables: `$vars.<variable-name>`

tabs.description: This is only applicable when you have a custom State at the START node. After agent execution, you might want to update the State values. Must return an object representing the state

tabs.label: Update State (Table)
tabs.name: updateStateMemoryUI

hint.label: How to use
hint.value:
1. Key and value pair to be updated. For example: if you have the following State:
    | Key       | Operation     | Default Value     |
    |-----------|---------------|-------------------|
    | user      | Replace       |                   |

    You can update the "user" value with the following:
    | Key       | Value     |
    |-----------|-----------|
    | user      | john doe  |

2. If you want to use the Tool Node's output as the value to update state, it is available as available as `$flow.output` with the following structure (array):
    ```json
    [
        {
            "tool": "tool's name",
            "toolInput": {},
            "toolOutput": "tool's output content",
            "sourceDocuments": [
                {
                    "pageContent": "This is the page content",
                    "metadata": "{foo: var}"
                }
            ]
        }
    ]
    ```

    For example:
    | Key          | Value                                     |
    |--------------|-------------------------------------------|
    | sources      | `$flow.output[0].toolOutput`       |

3. You can get default flow config, including the current "state":
    - `$flow.sessionId`
    - `$flow.chatId`
    - `$flow.chatflowId`
    - `$flow.input`
    - `$flow.state`

4. You can get custom variables: `$vars.<variable-name>`

tabs.description: This is only applicable when you have a custom State at the START node. After tool execution, you might want to update the State values

inputParams.label: Prepend Messages History
inputParams.name: messageHistory
inputParams.description: Prepend a list of messages between System Prompt and Human Prompt. This is useful when you want to provide few shot examples

inputParams.label: Conversation History
inputParams.name: conversationHistorySelection

options.label: User Question
options.name: user_question
options.description: Use the user question from the historical conversation messages as input.

options.label: Last Conversation Message
options.name: last_message
options.description: Use the last conversation message from the historical conversation messages as input.

options.label: All Conversation Messages
options.name: all_messages
options.description: Use all conversation messages from the historical conversation messages as input.

options.label: Empty
options.name: empty
options.description: Do not use any messages from the conversation history. Ensure to use either System Prompt, Human Prompt, or Messages History.

inputParams.description: Select which messages from the conversation history to include in the prompt. The selected messages will be inserted between the System Prompt (if defined) and [Messages History, Human Prompt].

inputParams.label: Human Prompt
inputParams.name: humanMessagePrompt
inputParams.description: This prompt will be added at the end of the messages as human message

inputParams.label: Format Prompt Values
inputParams.name: promptValues
inputParams.description: Assign values to the prompt variables. You can also use $flow.state.<variable-name> to get the state value

inputParams.label: JSON Structured Output
inputParams.name: llmStructuredOutput
inputParams.description: Instruct the LLM to give output in a JSON structured schema

tabs.label: Update State (Table)
tabs.name: updateStateMemoryUI

hint.label: How to use
hint.value:
1. Key and value pair to be updated. For example: if you have the following State:
    | Key       | Operation     | Default Value     |
    |-----------|---------------|-------------------|
    | user      | Replace       |                   |

    You can update the "user" value with the following:
    | Key       | Value     |
    |-----------|-----------|
    | user      | john doe  |

2. If you want to use the LLM Node's output as the value to update state, it is available as available as `$flow.output` with the following structure:
    ```json
    {
        "content": 'Hello! How can I assist you today?',
        "name": "",
        "additional_kwargs": {},
        "response_metadata": {},
        "tool_calls": [],
        "invalid_tool_calls": [],
        "usage_metadata": {}
    }
    ```

    For example, if the output `content` is the value you want to update the state with, you can do the following:
    | Key       | Value                     |
    |-----------|---------------------------|
    | user      | `$flow.output.content`  |

3. You can get default flow config, including the current "state":
    - `$flow.sessionId`
    - `$flow.chatId`
    - `$flow.chatflowId`
    - `$flow.input`
    - `$flow.state`

4. You can get custom variables: `$vars.<variable-name>`

tabs.description: This is only applicable when you have a custom State at the START node. After agent execution, you might want to update the State values

tabs.label: Update State (Code)
tabs.name: updateStateMemoryCode

hint.label: How to use
hint.value:
1. Return the key value JSON object. For example: if you have the following State:
    ```json
    {
        "user": null
    }
    ```

    You can update the "user" value by returning the following:
    ```js
    return {
        "user": "john doe"
    }
    ```

2. If you want to use the LLM Node's output as the value to update state, it is available as `$flow.output` with the following structure:
    ```json
    {
        "content": 'Hello! How can I assist you today?',
        "name": "",
        "additional_kwargs": {},
        "response_metadata": {},
        "tool_calls": [],
        "invalid_tool_calls": [],
        "usage_metadata": {}
    }
    ```

    For example, if the output `content` is the value you want to update the state with, you can return the following:
    ```js
    return {
        "user": $flow.output.content
    }
    ```

3. You can also get default flow config, including the current "state":
    - `$flow.sessionId`
    - `$flow.chatId`
    - `$flow.chatflowId`
    - `$flow.input`
    - `$flow.state`

4. You can get custom variables: `$vars.<variable-name>`

tabs.description: This is only applicable when you have a custom State at the START node. After agent execution, you might want to update the State values. Must return an object representing the state
